Formally, True is a Python built-in constant of bool type.
You can use Boolean operations on bool types (at the interactive python prompt for example) and convert numbers into bool types:

code:
>>> print not True
False
>>> print not False
True
>>> print True or False
True
>>> print True and False
False
>>> a=bool(9)
>>> print a
True
>>> b=bool(0)
>>> print b
False
>>> b=bool(0.000000000000000000000000000000000001)
>>> print b
True

text: And there are "gotcha's" potentially with what you see and what the Python compiler sees:

code:
>>> n=0
>>> print bool(n)
False
>>> n='0'
>>> print bool(n)
True
>>> n=0.0
>>> print bool(n)
False
>>> n="0.0"
>>> print bool(n)
True

text: As a hint of how Python stores bool types internally, you can cast bool types to integers and True will come out to be 1 and False 0:

code:
>>> print True+0
1
>>> print True+1
2
>>> print False+0
0
>>> print False+1
1

text: There are many algorithms where you want to process something until you find what you are looking for.
Hence the infinite loop or indefinite loop.
Each language tend to have its own idiom for these constructs.
Here are common C infinite loops, which also work for Perl:

code:
for(;;) { /* loop until break */ }
while (1) {
   return if (function(arg) > 3);
}
